titleStmt.title: Uninephrectomy and apical fluid shear stress decrease ENaC abundance in collecting duct principal cells

affiliation.orgName: Department of Cell Physiology and Metabolism

analytic.title: Uninephrectomy and apical fluid shear stress decrease ENaC abundance in collecting duct principal cells

biblStruct.note: Submitted 13 April 2017; accepted in final form 28 August 2017

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: Acute nephron reduction such as after living kidney donation may increase the risk of hypertension.
Uninephrectomy induces major hemodynamic changes in the remaining kidney, resulting in rapid increase of single-nephron glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and fluid delivery in the distal nephron.
Decreased sodium (Na) fractional reabsorption after the distal tubule has been reported after uninephrectomy in animals preserving volume homeostasis.
In the present study, we thought to specifically explore the effect of unilateral nephrectomy on epithelial Na channel (ENaC) subunit expression in mice.

We show that ␥-ENaC subunit surface expression was specifically downregulated after uninephrectomy, whereas the expression of the aldosterone-sensitive ␣-ENaC and ␣1-Na-K-ATPase subunits as well as of kidney-specific Na-K-Cl cotransporter isoform and Na-Cl cotransporter were not significantly altered.

Because acute nephron reduction induces a rapid increase of single-nephron GFR, resulting in a higher tubular fluid flow, we speculated that local mechanical factors such as fluid shear stress (FSS) were involved in Na reabsorption regulation after uninephrectomy.
We further explore such hypothesis in an in vitro model of FSS applied on highly differentiated collecting duct principal cells.
We found that FSS specifically downregulates ␤-ENaC and ␥-ENaC subunits at the transcriptional level through an unidentified heatinsensitive paracrine basolateral factor.
The primary cilium as a potential mechanosensor was not required.
In contrast, protein kinase A and calcium-sensitive cytosolic phospholipase A2 were involved, but we could not demonstrate a role for cyclooxygenase or epoxygenase metabolites.
Renal transplantation remains the best treatment for endstage renal disease but is limited by organ supply.

For this reason, living kidney donation increased considerably worldwide and represents nearly one-third of kidney transplantation in the United States and in other countries with advanced transplantation programs (30).

Long-term outcomes and safety of kidney donation are considered overall excellent, and life expectancy of living kidney donors is at least as good if not longer than the general population thanks to a careful selection of donors and in spite of the acute nephron loss (16,25).
Conflicting data nevertheless suggest an increased risk for hypertension and albuminuria (28,44), which has not been directly associated with worst renal outcome yet (16).

Understanding the physiological consequences of uninephrectomy is therefore of prime importance, and considerable efforts have already been made to delineate early and late hemodynamic glomerular changes after kidney donation (30).
However, regarding blood pressure regulation and body volume homeostasis, the effects of uninephrectomy on Na homeostasis remain poorly defined.

Uninephrectomy induces major hemodynamic changes in the remaining kidney, resulting in rapid increase of single-nephron glomerular filtration rate (GFR) initially through a rapid increase of renal blood flow and later through cortical hypertrophy and increased kidney volume.

In a recent report in humans, this adaptive process results in a 40% increase of single-kidney GFR from 47 (predonation) to 64, and 66 ml•min Ϫ1 •1.73 m Ϫ2 at 0.8 and 6.1 yr (median) after donation, respectively (30).
This results in a tubular flow increase of a similar extent and overall an increase in Na and fluid reabsorption per nephron to maintain body fluid homeostasis.
However, fractional Na reabsorption of the remaining kidney decreases.
Early micropuncture experiments performed in rats showed that single-nephron GFR increased without change in proximal tubule reabsorption (22).
Later micropuncture experiments in uninephrectomized rats by Shirley and Walter (42) showed increased Na excretion by the remnant kidney despite unchanged Na delivery to the late distal tubule.
This implies an inhibition of epithelial Na channel (ENaC)-mediated Na reabsorption in downstream segments, i.e., connecting tubule and collecting duct.
In addition, fluid delivery to the late distal tubule was increased, leading to increased tubular flow in downstream segments.
The decreased Na excretion observed in uninephrectomized animals was not related to plasma aldosterone drop (41).
The underlying mechanisms are yet to be determined but may involve tubular flow-mediated ENaC regulation that is important and physiologically relevant in volume homeostasis.
Disturbance of this adaptive increase in Na excretion by the remnant kidney may contribute to the increased risk of hypertension after living kidney donation.
In the present study, we thought to specifically explore the effect of unilateral nephrectomy on ENaC subunit expression in mice.

We also speculated that local mechanical forces may be involved in Na tubular reabsorption regulation, and we specifically explored how sustained increased luminal fluid shear stress (FSS) alters ENaC subunit expression in collecting duct principal cells in vitro.
Animals.
Male (6 -8 wk of age) C57B6 mice (Charles-River, Saint Germain de l'Arbresle, France) were housed under temperature-and humidity-controlled conditions with a 12:12-h light-dark cycle.
Mice were randomly assigned to undergo uninephrectomy (UNX) or a sham procedure.
UNX was performed through a small incision in the flank of isoflurane-anesthetized mice.
The renal vein and artery and the ureter were ligated, and the right kidney was removed.
In sham animals, the same flank incision was performed, allowing access to the right kidney, which was visualized and left in place.
All mice were administered intraperitoneal buprenorphine at the time of surgery and 250 l of prewarmed saline solution after surgery to reduce postoperative risk of hypovolemia.
The ethical committee of the University of Geneva and governmental authorities approved animal experiments.
In situ mouse kidney biotinylation.
Renal plasma membranes were biotinylated in situ as previously described with some modifications (18,50).

Kidneys were perfused with heparinized TBS for washing, and then they were perfused with 0.5 mg/ml sulfosuccinimidyl-2-[biotinamido]ethyl-1,3-dithiopropionate (Campbell Science, Rockville, IL) at a rate of 1ml/min for 30 min with a minipump, through the abdominal aorta.
The reaction was stopped, and excess biotin was removed by further perfusing TBS for 10 min.

At the end of the perfusion, the left kidney was quickly removed, minced with a razor blade, and homogenized with a tight-fitting Dounce in 8 ml of lysis buffer containing 250 mM sucrose, 10 mM triethanolamine hydrochloride, 1.6 mM ethanolamine, 0.5 EDTA at pH 7.40, and 60 l protease inhibitor cocktail (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO).
The homogenate was centrifuged at 1,000 g for 10 min to separate intact tissue; supernatant was collected and frozen at Ϫ80°C for later use.
The samples then centrifuged at 100,000 g for 2 h to sediment cell membranes.
The pellet was resuspended in 2 ml of lysis buffer, separated into aliquots, and frozen at Ϫ80°C for later analysis.
Protein concentrations were measured with a micro-BCA reagent kit (Pierce, Rockford, IL).
Biotinylated proteins were isolated using Neutravidin Ultralink beads (Pierce) (19,50).
Immunoblotting.
Proteins (10 g) extracted from kidney cortex were solubilized at 95°C for 5 min in Laemmli buffer and stored at Ϫ20°C until use.

Cultured cells were lysed in homogenizing buffer (20 mM Tris pH 7.4, 2 mM EGTA, 2 mM EDTA, 30 mM NaF, 30 mM Na 4P2O7, and 2 mM Na3VO4) supplemented with 0.01% SDS, 1% Triton X-100, and an anti-protease cocktail (Complete Mini; Roche, Mannheim, Germany).
Proteins were subjected to SDS-PAGE and transferred to polyvinylidene difluoride membranes (Immobilon-P; Millipore, Billerica, MA).

After blocking in TBS-Tween buffer (50 mm Tris base, 150 mm NaCl, 0.1% Tween) containing 5% nonfat dried milk, blots were incubated with the following specific antibodies: ␣-ENaC, ␤-ENaC, ␥-ENaC, kidney-specific Na-K-Cl cotransporter isoform (NKCC2), kidney-specific Na-K-Cl cotransporter isoform (NCC) [gifts from J. Loffing (43,45)], SGK1 (Sigma-Aldrich), ␤-actin (Sigma-Aldrich), E-cadherin, anti-␤-actin (Sigma-Aldrich), Kif3A (Abcam, Cambridge, UK), protein kinase A (PKA) P substrates (Cell Signaling, Danvers, MA), and phospho-cAMP response element-binding protein (CREB; Cell Signaling).

Horseradish peroxidase-conjugated anti-rabbit or anti-mouse IgG secondary antibodies (BD Biosciences PharMingen, Franklin Lakes, NJ) were used for detection of immunoreactive proteins by enhanced chemiluminescence (Millipore).
Bands were quantified with ImageJ software (National Institutes of Health).
Results were expressed as a ratio of GAPDH and normalized to one for the control condition.
Cell culture and equivalent short-circuit current measurement.
Cultured mouse cortical collecting duct cells mCCD Cl1 (21) and derived cell lines were seeded on semipermeable filters (Transwell; Corning Costar, Cambridge, MA).
The culture medium was a 1:1 mixture of Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium and F-12 medium with Glutamax (DMEM/F12, catalog no.

31331; Invitrogen-GIBCO, Bern, Switzerland) supplemented with 2% fetal calf serum (Invitrogen-GIBCO), 5 g/ml insulin (Sigma, St. Louis, MO), 5 g/ml holotransferrin (Sigma), 10 ng/ml epidermal growth factor (Pepro-Tech, London, UK), 50 nM dexamethasone (Sigma), 60 nM sodium selenite (Sigma), and 1 nM 3,3=,5-triiodo-L-thyronin (Sigma).

Where indicated, cells were treated with PKA inhibitor 14 -22 amide (PKI; Merk Millipore), calcium-sensitive cytosolic phospholipase A2 (cPLA2) inhibitor (Calbiochem), indomethacine (Sigma), cycloheximide (Sigma-Aldrich), actinomycin D (Sigma-Aldrich), 11,12-epoxyeicosa-5Z,8Z,14Z-trienoic acid (EET; Enzo Life Sciences), and N-(methylsulfonyl)-2-(2-propynyloxy)-benzenehexanamide (MS-PPOH; Cayman Chemical).
Direct transepithelial potential differences and resistance were measured with a Millicell device (Millipore), as previously described (48).
Transepithelial equivalent short-circuit current could be calculated following Ohm's law.
Results were normalized to one for the control condition.
ENaC-specific current was assessed using 10 Ϫ6 M benzamil treatment added to the apical medium for 30 min.
Flow.
Flow was applied using an orbital shaker (orbital shaker SSM1; VWR) placed inside a cell culture incubator as previously described (10,29).
The orbital radius was 8 mm, and we assume a culture medium viscosity of 0.01 poise and a density of 0.9973 g/ml as previously estimated (10).

To generate a FSS of 2 dyn/cm 2 , we calculated that the shaker has to be set at 82 revolutions/min (rpm) as estimated by the following formula: a ͙ ͑2f͒ 3 , where a is the orbital radius of rotation of the shaker, is the density of the culture medium, is the viscosity of the medium, and f is the frequency of rotation (rpm) (10).
Constructs and viral particles production.

For conditional expression of short-hairpin RNA (shRNA), Kif3A targeting sequences 5=-CTCCGCCAGTTTCAGAAAGAAA-3= were subcloned between the restriction sites XhoI and EcoRI of the pTRIPZ-inducible lentiviral vector (Thermo Scientific, Waltham, MA), which expresses shRNA in the genomic context of the human miRNA-30 together with a puromycin-resistance gene (constitutive expression), the rtTA3 (constitutive expression), and the turbo red fluorescent protein (inducible expression).
The nonsilencing (scramble) shRNA expressing pTRIPZ was commercially available (RHS4743; Thermo Scientific).
Lentiviral particles production was performed as previously described (Nunes, no.
To generate stable cell lines conditionally expressing shRNA, mCCDCl1 cells were transduced using concentrated lentiviral particles.
Puromycin selection (2 g/ml) was applied 24 h after transduction.
After 72 h, polyclonal cell lines were maintained in low-dose puromycin (0.5 g/ml).
All experiments were performed without puromycin, and overnight pretreatment with 0.5 g/ml of doxycyclin (Dox) was used to induce the expression of the shRNA.
Real-time quantitative PCR analysis.
RNA extraction, reverse transcription, and real-time PCR analysis were performed as previously described (9).

The following primers were used for cDNA quantification: ribosomal protein P0 5=-AATCTCCAGAGGCACCATTG and 5=-GTTCAGCATGTTCAGCAGTG, Kif3A 5=-ATGCCGATCAATAA-GTCGGAGA and 5=-GTTCCCCTCATTTCATCCACG, ␣-ENaC 5=-CAGACTTGGAGCTTTGACAAGGA and 5=-ACTTCTCTGTGCCT-TGTTTATATGTGTT, ␤-ENaC 5=-CAGACTGGGCCTATTGCTA-TCTAAA and 5=-ACATGCTGAGGCAGGTCTCTCT, ␥-ENaC 5=-CCGAGATCGAGACAGCAATGT and 5=-CGCTCAGCTTGAAGG-ATTCTG, SGK1 5=-CCAAACCCTCCGACTTTCAC and 5=-CCTT-GTGCCTAGCCAGAAGAA, ␣1-Na-K-ATPase 5= TCCCTTCAACTC-CACCAACAA and 5=-TTTGGGCTCAGATGCATTTG, ␤-Na-K-AT-Pase 5=-TCGGAGAAGAAGGAGTTTTTGG and 5=-GCAGCCAT-AAAATATCACGTAGAACA, NHE3 5=-CAGGTGGTCACCTTCA-AATG-3= and 5=-GGGACAGGTGAAAGACGATT-3=, NKCC2 5=-TGGGTTGTCAACTTCTGCAA and 5=-GCTCCGGGAAATCAGG-
ENaC INHIBITION BY SHEAR STRESS TAGT, and NCC 5=-ACCACCATCTCCTACCTTGC-3= and 5=-GGAGTCATGGTGTCGTTCAC-3=.
Data were analyzed and reported according to the 2 -⌬⌬Ct method.
Statistics. Results are given as means Ϯ SE from n independent experiments.
Comparisons between two groups were performed by unpaired Student's t-test if not stated otherwise.
Comparisons between more than two groups were performed by ANOVA and Dunnet's t-test.
A P value Ͻ0.05 was considered significant.
Uninephrectomy does not induce a downregulation of aldosterone-controlled ␣-ENaC.

Fractional excretion of Na (FE-Na) significantly increases after uninephrectomy, and a previous study suggested that this occurs through decreased tubular Na reabsorption occurring distally to the late distal tubule (42).
Therefore, we first examined the effect of acute nephron reduction on ENaC subunit expression in renal cortex of uninephrectomized mice after 24 h.

Total protein expression (Fig. 1, A and B) of the aldosterone-regulated ENaC ␣-subunit (␣-ENaC) and the aldosterone-induced regulatory kinase SGK1 did not significantly change between sham-operated and uninephrectomized animals.
In contrast, we did not observe significant differences at the transcriptional levels (Fig. 1C).
Aldosterone urinary excretion was measured before and after surgery in Ctl and Unix animals (Fig. 1D).
As previously reported (41), we did not observe significant differences in aldosterone secretion after uninephrectomy.
In contrast to unchanged ␣-ENaC protein, total ␥-ENaC protein abundance significantly decreased by 29% (Fig. 1, A and B).
It should be mentioned that we could not detect the cleaved ␥-ENaC subunits in total protein extracts.
We could not reproducibly detect ␤-ENaC because of the poor background-to-signal ratio of available antibodies.
Therefore, diminution of ␥-ENaC expression could account for a decrease in Na reabsorption observed after uninephrectomy, but through a mechanism independent of aldosterone regulation.

Cell surface expression of ␥-ENaC is specifically downregulated in the remaining kidney after uninephrectomy, whereas ␣-ENaC, ␣ 1 -Na-K-ATPase as well as NKCC2 and NCC expression was not significantly altered.
Surface protein expression of ENaC subunits determines the apical Na permeability and the Na reabsorption capacity of the aldosterone-sensitive nephron.
In addition, aldosterone does not only affect mRNA expression but also ␣-ENaC subunit trafficking toward the apical membrane (33,34).
Therefore, we further assessed surface protein expression of ENaC subunits in uninephrectomized animals using biotin renal perfusion before protein extraction as previously described ( 50).

This method allowed the specific isolation of membrane surface protein from renal cortical tissue as assessed by the strong signal for E-cadherin (epithelial surface protein) and the absence of GAPDH signal (cytosolic housekeeping protein) in immunoblots (Fig. 2A).
We confirmed that ␣-ENaC protein surface expression did not change after uninephrectomy.
In contrast, the ␥-ENaC subunit surface expression significantly decreased by nearly 50 and 70% for the 85-kDa full-length and 70-kDa cleaved bands, respectively.

At the same time, we examined the surface expression of the main Na apical transporter of the thick loop of Henle (NKCC2) and of the distal tubule (NCC) that did not significantly change between sham-operated and uninephrectomized animals.
The basolateral expression of the Na-K-

Ctl (sham) Unix Taken together this further confirms that the FE-Na increase observed after acute nephron reduction occurred through a diminution of ENaC expression, and specifically through a marked reduction of the total and cleaved ␥-ENaC subunit surface expression while the ␣-ENaC subunit abundance remained unchanged.
Fluid shear stress decreases Na transcellular reabsorption in an in vitro model of collecting duct principal cells.
In animal models or after living kidney donation, uninephrectomy is shortly followed by increased single-nephron GRF (30,42).
This implies an increase of tubular fluid flow that applies FSS on tubular epithelial cells.

Because aldosterone-sensitive ␣-ENaC regulation was not involved in decreased FE-Na after acute nephron reduction, we speculate that local mechanical forces such as FSS directly regulate Na absorption in the distal nephron.

Therefore, to explore how FSS affects transepithelial Na transport in principal collecting duct cells, we developed an in vitro model using mCCD cl1 cells, a well-differentiated mouse collecting duct principal cell line expressing ENaC and responsive to physiological levels of vasopressin and aldosterone (21).

mCCD cl1 cells were grown on polycarbonate filters, allowing direct transepithelial potential differences and resistance measurements; next, transepithelial short-circuit current could be calculated following Ohm's law.
A directional flow was generated using an orbital shaker as previously described (29).
We generated a FSS estimated at 2 dyn/cm 2 following previously validated calculation in a similar setting (10).
This shear stress is in the upper range of the physiological amplitude estimated in tubular lumen (2,32).

FSS decreased significantly the transepithelial current after 8 and 24 h compared with the static condition, as assessed by a decreased potential difference but a preserved transepithelial resistance.
There were no significant differences after 1 h, but a clear trend to a decreased transepithelial current was observed after 4 h (Fig. 3A).

The transepithelial current also decreased under static conditions, but to a lesser extent, since cells were starved 24 h before and during the experiments to limit any potential hormonal interference.

When the apical Na channel ENaC was blocked using benzamil, there was no difference in transepithelial current between static and flow conditions, demonstrating that the reduced transepithelial current was the result of a decreased transcellular Na current through ENaC (Fig. 3B).
Fluid shear stress induces the downregulation of ␤and ␥-ENaC subunits, but not of ␣-ENaC.
Next, we assessed whether FSS was specifically regulating ␤and ␥-ENaC as observed in vivo after acute nephron reduction.
Western blots for ENaC subunits were performed with total protein extracts from mCCD cl1 cells subjected to static or flow conditions for 24 h.
␣-ENaC protein expression remained unchanged, whereas ␥-ENaC protein expression significantly decreased by ϳ90% (Fig. 4, A and B).

Transcriptional analysis of ENaC and Na-K-ATPase subunit mRNA expression was also performed at various time points, showing a transcriptional downregulation specifically of ␤and ␥-ENaC and ␤-Na-K-ATPase that was significant after 8 and 24 h, but not after 4 h of FSS (Fig. 5A), replicating the timeframe of the Na transepithelial current decrement previously observed (Fig. 3A).
In contrast, ␣-ENaC and ␣ 1 -Na-K-ATPase subunit mRNA were not altered by FSS (Fig. 5A).

In addition, we pretreated cells with cycloheximide (CHX), a protein synthesis inhibitor, or actinomycin D (ACTD), an RNA synthesis inhibitor, to assess whether de novo protein or RNA synthesis was required for FSS-mediated downregulation of ␤and ␥-ENaC mRNA.

CHX did not prevent the downregulation of ENaC or Na-K-ATPase subunit mRNA expression induced by FSS (Fig. 5B), which suggests that a specific de novo translated transcription factor is not directly involved.

The strong decrease in ␤and ␥-ENaC mRNA expression observed in CHX-treated cells suggests the presence of an intermediate protein with a short half-life that positively regulates the transcriptional expression of these two ENaC subunits.
However, FSS did not further decrease ␤and ␥-ENaC mRNA expression in cells pretreated with ACD, indicating that diminution of ENaC subunit mRNA levels relies on a transcriptional inhibition.
FSS mediates the production of a basolateral heat-insensitive factor that downregulates Na reabsorption.
Next, we speculated that FSS induces the production of a local paracrine/ autocrine secreted factor that influences Na reabsorption.
To explore this hypothesis, we exposed static mCCD cl1 cells to culture media from either the apical or the basolateral sides of other cells subjected to FSS overnight.
Only the basolateral medium transfer recapitulated the FSS phenotype and induced a decrease of transepithelial current significant after 4 h of exposure that was sustained up to 24 h (Fig. 6A).
This effect was preserved after boiling the culture medium, indicating a heat-insensitive factor (Fig. 6B).
Fluid shear stress-mediated downregulation of collecting duct Na reabsorption does not require a functional primary cilium.
Renal tubular cells are able to sense FSS in vitro through the bending of the apical primary cilium (38).
Therefore, we explored whether the primary cilium was involved in the mechanotransduction of FSS and the downregulation of transepithelial Na transport in our in vitro model.
ENaC INHIBITION BY SHEAR STRESS duced mCCD cl1 cells with a doxycycline-inducible miRNA construct KIF3A, an anterograde kinesin required for primary cilium development (31).
silencing of KIF3A was obtained at the and protein levels after doxycycline (Dox) pretreatment (Fig. 7, A and B).
Silencing of KIF3A did not prevent the decrease of transepithelial current induced by FSS (Fig. 7C), suggesting that the primary cilium is not required for FSS mechanotransduction in this setting.

PKA and phospholipase A 2 are both required in the pathway involved in shear stress-mediated downregulation of collecting duct Na reabsorption, but the cyclooxygenase and epoxygenase pathways are not involved.
Finally, we explored which signaling pathways triggered by FSS may be involved in shear stress-mediated downregulation of Na reabsorption in collecting duct cells.
We specifically looked at PKA and phospholipase A 2 (PLA 2 ) activation, since both pathways have been previously involved in cell mechanotransduction and ENaC regulation.
Western blots for total phospho-PKA substrates and phospho-CREB were performed with total protein extracts from mCCD cl1 cells subjected to static or flow conditions.
An overall increased pattern of PKA phospho-substrates was observed under flow conditions (Fig. 8A), and phospho-CREB was significantly increased by 40% (Fig. 8, A and B).
In addition, small peptide PKA inhibitor (PKI) pretreatment of mCCD cl1 cells subjected to FSS prevented the shear stressmediated current decrease (Fig. 8C).
Specific cPLA 2 inhibition also partially prevented the shear stress-mediated current decrease (Fig. 8D).
This effect could not be reproduced with indomethacin, an inhibitor of the cyclooxygenase pathway that already decreased transepithelial current under static conditions (Fig. 8D).
We further explore whether the epoxygenase pathway was involved.
It was previously shown that EET inhibits ENaC open probability (47) and ␥-ENaC expression in inner medullary collecting duct (46).
The role of the epoxygenase pathway in regulating ENaC activity was further demonstrated in Cyp2c44 knockout mice that exhibit a Na-dependent hypertension (5).

Overexpression of human CYP2C8 together with ENaC subunits in CHO cells decreased ENaC activity, and this effect was prevented by selective epoxygenase inhibitor MS-PPOH or a PKA inhibitor (PKI) (37).
Therefore, we tested the hypothesis that shear stress was inducing production, subsequently inhibiting ENaC expression in mCCD cells.
However, EET either on the apical or the basolateral side of static mCCD cells did not alter the transepithelial short-circuit current (Fig. 9A).
Also, pretreatment of mCCD cells with MS-PPOH, a specific epoxygenase inhibitor, did not prevent FSS-mediated inhibition of ENaC activity (Fig. 9B).
In the present study, we have found that ␥-ENaC subunit cell surface expression was decreased after uninephrectomy, whereas ␣-ENaC expression remained mostly unchanged.
This certainly explains the increased Na urinary excretion per kidney at 2-5 h, days 5 and 30 after rat uninephrectomy (42).

Despite that increased single-nephron GFR imposes an increase in the absolute amount of Na reabsorbed per nephron, a concomitant rapid adaptive response is expected to decrease fractional Na reabsorption to maintain body volume homeostasis after acute nephron reduction.

Because late distal Na delivery was not increased after uninephrectomy as assessed by micropuncture measurements (42), this could be entirely explained by a reduction in fractional Na reabsorption in the connecting tubules and collecting ducts, consistent with the reduction of ENaC activity that we found.

Depending on Na, fluid intake, and volemia, tubular cells are subjected to frequent variations of intraluminal flow that applies various mechanical forces that include shear stress but also hydrostatic pressure and membrane stretch.

Flow-mediated mechanical forces trigger various cellular responses in tubular cells, including increased reabsorption in proximal tubule and collecting duct cells, increased HCO Ϫ reabsorption in proximal tubular cells, and increased potassium secretion in collecting duct cells (8,49).
Acute nephron reduction is shortly followed by increased renal blood flow and glomerular filtration rate in the remaining kidney with a subsequent acceleration of tubular flow.
This increases FSS applied on renal tubular cells, and we speculated that FSS was linked to ␥-ENaC regulation.

Therefore, we thought to examine whether sustained increased FSS in the collecting duct would alter ENaC subunit expression and recapitulate the regulatory pattern that we found in vivo after acute nephron reduction.

We developed an in vitro model to specifically apply a directional shear stress force, without modifying the hydrostatic pressure or stretch force, on a well-described and differentiated collecting duct principal cell line (mCCD Cl1 ) grown on a polycarbonate filter to ensure that they fully developed a polarized cell monolayer.

In concordance with our in vivo data, we found that sustained FSS significantly decreased ENaC activity in a delayed time frame through a transcriptional inhibition of the ␤and ␥-ENaC subunits, whereas ␣-ENaC subunit expression remained unchanged, involving a PKA-and cPLA 2 -dependent pathway and the production of a basolateral paracrine factor.
Decreased ENaC activity and expression is in contrast to the current paradigm that FSS increases ENaC activity as shown in previous in vitro and ex vivo studies (2,6,35,40).
In vitro, laminar shear stress (ranging from 0.2 to 5.1 dyn/cm 2 ) increased the amiloride-sensitive current in Xenopus oocytes-overexpressing mouse (6,40), rat or Xenopus (2) cloned ENaC subunits.

This was the result of an increased channel open probability through a conformational change in the second transmembrane region of the ENaC ␣-subunit and did not involve the recruitment of new channels from an intracellular pool or an increase in the number of active channels through proteolytic activity (1,2,6,7,35).

Similar results were obtained in ex vivo microperfused rabbit collecting duct with increasing tubular fluid perfusion rate; an increase of Na channel open probability was observed while trafficking of new ENaC to the membrane surface or additional protease activation was not required (35,40).
Although an increase in perfusion flow does enhance Na reabsorption in microperfused tubule, other mechanical forces than shear stress alone can be accounted for.
Indeed, when perfusion is increased, rabbit CCD also significantly dilates, implying increased hydrostatic pressure and tubular cell membrane stretch (32).
When shear stress alone is increased using 5.5-fold higher luminal viscosity by adding dextran to the perfusion medium of microdissected collecting duct, Na reabsorption was not altered (40).
In addition, all of these observations were made on a short time frame, whereas, in our in vitro model, a longer time frame was performed allowing transcriptional and translation regulation to occur.

Our findings and previous in vitro and ex vivo data are not necessarily exclusive: we could segregate FSS effects on collecting duct principal cells in a short-term adapting mechanosensitive mechanism that increases ENaC activity through an increase in channel open probability, putatively to protect the glomerulotubular balance; while under a more sustained increase in FSS, different regulatory pathways are engaged that limit tubular Na reabsorption through a transcriptional regulation of ␤and ␥-ENaC subunits to maintain the body volume homeostasis.

In addition, shear stress-mediated increase of open probability of ENaC may also participate in other mechanosensitive apparatus in non-Na-absorbing cells expressing ENaC such as arteries and nerve ending cells, as previously suggested (2,(12)(13)(14)20), but may not be directly involved in volume homeostasis.
Interestingly, ␣-ENaC transcription and its cell surface expression are regulated by aldosterone to control ENaC activity.
Nevertheless, in vivo after uninephrectomy or in vitro in cells subjected to FSS, ␤and ␥-ENaC subunits were specifically downregulated, independent of the aldosterone pathway.

The ␥-ENaC subunit is also a rate-limiting subunit for ENaCdependent Na reabsorption in collecting duct principal cells, as shown in previous independent studies (24,48), although its expression is not directly regulated by aldosterone in the kidney (3).
Therefore ␥-ENaC reduction is most likely sufficient to decrease collecting duct fraction reabsorption of Na as observed after uninephrectomy.
We recently described a similar pattern of transcriptional regulation of ENaC subunits after hyperosmolality-mediated endoplasmic reticulum stress (9).
In the colon, a specific regulation of ␤and ␥-ENaC subunits was also observed after aldosterone or dexamethasone treatment in rats (3).

This suggests the presence of an underappreciated specific regulatory pathway of ␤and ␥-ENaC subunits, uncoupled from ␣-ENaC regulation, which appears to be aldosterone sensitive in the but not in the cortex.
␥-ENaC protein expression is significantly reduced both in vivo after uninephrectomy and in cultured cells exposed to apical shear stress.

The role of shear stress in ENaC regulation after uninephrectomy is an attractive hypothesis, but it remains speculative, and we cannot exclude unrelated mechanisms behind ␥-ENaC regulation after uninephrectomy or in cells exposed to shear stress.

In collecting duct cells, the primary cilium is able to sense increased luminal flow by inducing intracellular calcium influx through the polycystine-1 and Ϫ2 complex located at its basal body (36,39,49).
Therefore, the primary cilium acts as a mechanosensing structure able to trigger signal when FSS increases.
However, in our in vitro setting, a functional primary cilium was not required, as demonstrated in cells silenced for KIF3A, an anterograde kinesin essential for primary cilium formation (31).

Nevertheless, other cellular features are susceptible to sense mechanical forces, including the cytoskeleton per se in tall epithelial cells, basolateral adhesive molecules such as integrins, force-induced protein unfolding that may activate enzymatic properties, or other mechanosensitive membrane channel (23).

As already mentioned, ENaC itself appears to be a mechanosensitive channel: a specific sequence of the second transmembrane region of the ␣-ENaC is able to sense luminal FSS by hypothetically undergoing conformational changes and increasing the open probability of ENaC and Na reabsorption (1).
We observed an opposite effect on ENaC activity during a more sustained increase in FSS, and a more complex time-sensitive mechanosensitive attribute is likely involved.

In addition, we could speculate that increased Na delivery in the collecting duct and consequently intracellular Na concentration may regulate ␥-ENaC surface trafficking, but we mostly observed a transcriptional regulation, and in our in vitro model the apical Na concentration remained constant, making this hypothesis unlikely.

Increased cAMP intracellular concentration and PKA activation are expected to result in an increase of ENaC activity through both a higher open probability and enhanced trafficking of new ENaC to the apical membrane as observed, for instance, after vasopressin or forskolin treatment in vitro (4,27).
This contrasts with our observation that FSS-mediated decreased ENaC expression requires PKA activation.

Nevertheless, we could not determine whether PKA activation was required in the afferent mechanosensing pathway or involved in the effector pathway that resulted in the transcriptional inhibition of ␤and ␥-ENaC subunits.
We also found that PLA 2 was necessary for FSS-mediated decrease of ENaC expression.
A previous study demonstrated PLA 2 activation by FSS (17).

This was associated with increased production of prostaglandin E 2 by collecting duct cells in vitro that was repressing the increase of Na reabsorption in microperfused cortical collecting ducts subjected to high flow rate (17).
This contrasts with our model where cPLA 2 inhibi-tion prevented FSS-mediated decrease of ENaC expression, but not indomethacin.
This suggests that the cyclooxygenase pathway is not primarily involved and pointed to the epoxygenase pathway.
However, using EET or the epoxygenase inhibitor MS-PPOH, we could not demonstrate its implication in shear stress regulation of ENaC.
In summary, we have shown that acute nephron reduction induces the diminution of total and cell surface ␥-ENaC subunit expression.
This is in line with the previous observation that fractional Na reabsorption decreases in the collecting duct after uninephrectomy.

Because single-nephron GFR rapidly increases after nephron reduction together with accelerated fluid delivery in the collecting duct, we hypothesized that increased FSS mediates ␥-ENaC downregulation.

With this perspective, we found that FSS inhibits ␤and ␥-ENaC transcriptional expression through a PKA-and PLA 2 -dependent pathway and the secretion of a basolateral effector molecule yet to be identified.
This did not require a functional primary cilium.
Such pathway may be of importance in volume homeostasis and blood pressure control in vivo and could become a novel therapeutic target (15,26).
Fig.1.
A: Western blot of total proteins extracted from kidney cortex of control (Ctl) sham-operated or uninephrectomized (Unix) animals 24 h after surgery.
Immunoblot for ␣-epithelial Na channel (ENaC), ␥-ENaC, and SGK1 are shown as indicated.
␤-Actin immunoblot was used as loading control.
B: optical density (OD) of immunoblots from A normalized for the loading control ␤-actin OD.
Results represent means Ϯ SE from 6 animals in each group.

C: qPCR analysis of ENaC subunits, Na-K-ATPase, SGK1, and the other main tubular Na transporters of mRNA extracted from total kidney cortex of sham-operated or uninephrectomized animals 24 h after surgery.
Results represent means Ϯ SE of 6 animals in each group.
D: 24-h urinary excretion of aldosterone before and after uninephrectomy or sham operation.
Results represent means Ϯ SE of 6 animals in each group.
D-1, day Ϫ1 (day before surgery); D0, day 0 (day after surgery).
ENaC INHIBITION BY SHEAR STRESSATPase ␣ 1 -subunit did not significantly change either (Fig.2, B and C).
Fig. 2. A: Western blot of biotinylated cell surface proteins extracted from kidney cortex of control sham-operated or uninephrectomized animals.
Total proteins from kidney cortex were used as control.
Immunoblots for E-cadherin (cell surface protein) and GAPDH (cytosolic protein) are shown to confirm the high purity of cell surface biotinylated protein extraction.
B: Western blot of cell surface biotinylated proteins extracted from kidney cortex of control sham-operated or uninephrectomized animals 24 h after surgery.

Immunoblots for ␣-ENaC, ␥-ENaC [full length (FL) and cleaved (cleav) fragment], Na-K-ATPase, kidney-specific Na-K-Cl cotransporter isoform (NKCC2), and Na-Cl cotransporter (NCC) are shown as indicated.
C: OD of immunoblots from B. Results represent means Ϯ SE of 6 animals in each group.
Fig.3.

A: time course of potential differences (dP) and resistance (R) measurements of mCCDcl1 cells subjected to fluid shear stress (2 dyn/cm 2 ) (open squares and dotted line) or control static (open circles) conditions.
Short-circuit currents are calculated following Ohm's law (sc-I).
Data are normalized to time 0 measurement and are expressed as arbitrary units (a.u.).
Mean values Ϯ SE from 6 independent experiments are shown.
Two-way ANOVA followed by Bonferroni's multiple-comparisons test were performed.
B: ENaC-dependent transepithelial current was assessed using benzamil (BZM) treatment.
After 24 h of flow or static conditions, transepithelial potential differences and resistance were measured before and 30 min after BZM treatment.
Short-circuit transepithelial current was then calculated and is indicated as arbitrary units, normalized to static conditions before BZM treatment.
Means Ϯ SE of 3 independent experiments are shown.
ns, Statistically nonsignificant difference.
Fig. 4. A: Western blot of total proteins extracted from mCCDcl1 cells subjected to shear stress for 24 h or static conditions.
Immunoblots for ␣-ENaC and ␥-ENaC are shown as indicated.
␤-Actin was used as loading control.
Three representative sets of cells are shown.
B: OD of ENaC subunits normalized to the loading control actin OD.
Static condition is arbitrarily set at 1 (a.u.).
Means Ϯ SE are shown.
Quantification was made on 3 independent experiments.
Fig. 5. A: qPCR analysis of ENaC subunits and Na-K-ATPase subunit expression levels of mCCDcl1 cells subjected to shear stress or static conditions.
A time course at 4, 8, and 24 h is shown.
Relative expression is indicated normalized to static conditions for each time point arbitrarily set as 1 (broken line).
Results represent means Ϯ SE of 6 -10 independent experiments.
B: qPCR analysis of ENaC and Na-K-ATPase subunit expression levels of mCCDcl1 cells subjected to shear stress for 8 h and treated with cycloheximide (CHX) and actinomycin D (ACTD).
Relative expression is indicated normalized to static conditions of the control condition (no treatment) arbitrarily set as 1.
Empty and gray bars indicate static and flow conditions, respectively.
Mean Ϯ SE results of 3 independent experiments are shown.

Fig. 7. A: qPCR analysis of KIF3A mRNA expression in mCCDcl1 cells transduced with inducible control scramble [SCR short-hairpin RNA (shRNA)] or KIF3A (KIF3A shRNA) shRNAmir treated or not with doxycycline (Dox).
Relative foldchange compared with untreated scrambled (SCR) shRNAmir mCCDcl1 cells is shown.
The mean Ϯ SE results of 6 independent experiments are shown.
B: Western blot of total proteins from SCR and KIF3A shRNAmir transduced mCCDcl1 cells treated or not with doxycycline.
A representative immunoblot for KIF3A and ␤-actin is shown.
C: short-circuit current of mCCDcl1 cells transduced with inducible SCR or KIF3A targeting shRNAmir.
Silencing was induced with Dox pretreatment.
Data are normalized to control SCR shRNAmir untreated cells under static conditions and are expressed as arbitrary units.
Fig. 9. A: short-circuit current of static mCCDcl1 cells treated for 6 or 24 h with apical or basolateral (basolat) 1 M 11,12-epoxyeicosatrienoic acid (EET), as indicated.
Means Ϯ SE of 3 independent experiments are shown.

B: short-circuit current of mCCDcl1 cells pretreated with 45 M of N-(methylsulfonyl)-2-(2propynyloxy)-benzenehexanamide (MS-PPOH), an epoxygenase inhibitor, or control vehicle (DMSO) and subjected to flow or static conditions for 6 and 24 h.
Means Ϯ SE of 4 independent experiments are shown.
